message: What does your CI infrastructure look like? Do you have one at all? What are the ups and downs?
Does one know how/if Hudson and/or Jenkins will stay alive for the next couple of years or if one of them will "die"?
we don't do continuous deployment because we have a slightly different workflow and tons of branches coming and going into production
https://github.com/atmos/jinkies/wiki/Jenkins-Project-Setup
Though now, I would switch to using Jenkins (currently not using any CI)
@varikin That would be interesting. Found a post on that for Jenkins http://jenkins-ci.org/content/getting-started-building-android-apps-hudson
I have used Hudson and CruiseControl in the past, both for Java projects. Really like Hudson.
We use Jenkins at GitHub with custom extensions that work well for our workflow
https://github.com/atmos/jinkies
I am interested in how companies manage stuff like that, build management, release management and such things.
I *highly* recommend this video: http://us.pycon.org/2010/conference/schedule/event/109/
Could you live without CI? Should every software company use CI?
@atmos Is there like a blog post where one can find more about your workflow?
Would like to try integrating it into Android projects though

@skohler I would image Jenkins will stay alive quite a bit longer. It really is the true successor of Hudson. There is a large team/community behind it. That said, Oracle now seems to be pushing Hudson over to the Eclipse foundation. I will be interested to see where that leads.
@skohler soonish, yeah
i have to give a talk on it later this summer so i'll prollly do a blog post on it as well
@atmos Nice - looking forward to it!
We've used Cruise Control and now Jenkins. Here's our setup: http://pi-pixel.tumblr.com/tagged/beacon
The hardest part is setting up a new project with a new/different technology. Otherwise you can just start by copying other projects.

I'd consider it a serious red flag not to see CI on a project both for automated test runs and also as part of the deploy process. Continuous deployment isn't reasonable for every project and team (sadly) but a project should at least be able to trigger a reliable, consistent process for deploying to any environment with a single button press on your CI server.

Carbon Five has been using Team City for all of our recent projects. We probably have ~12 projects building at any given time, all on different technology stacks running a mix of ruby, objective-c, javascript, and occasionally java tests. I haven't found setting up new projects to be too much trouble with the hardest part being making sure that every build agent has required packages installed for every project it might build. Unfortunately we haven't had a chance to get chef/puppet added as a part of all of our projects yet.
I've been using Hudson/Jenkins for 2-3 years now for both Java and .NET apps.  I use it for build/test/deployment, but only for development/testing environments, not for production.
I really like open source CI tool Travis (additionally you can set up your own server) http://travis-ci.org

Jenkins seems to be the strongest CI choice these days, for almost any development environment/language.  I've used CruiseControl, Integrity, and a couple real small ones, and Jenkins just makes all the others seem feeble.
Again, I *highly* recommend this video: http://us.pycon.org/2010/conference/schedule/event/109/
Thanks @ all for the feedback!
@kennethreitz Thanks. Great talk. I watched it the other day.
